item.title: This fund strategist says there’s at least one way companies can survive Amazon’s onslaught
item.dc:creator: Philip van Doorn
item.description: Customer satisfaction is a differentiator in some industries, says ACSI Funds’ Kevin Quigg.
item.content:encoded:
DEEP DIVE
By Philip van Doorn

Customer satisfaction is a differentiator in some industries, says ACSI Funds’ Kevin Quigg

Stock pickers tend to screen companies for metrics including price-to-earnings ratios, analysts’ earnings estimates and profit margins.

But there’s a simpler approach in this long period of technological transformation that is threatening industries from retail to banking: customer satisfaction.

See: Every time this happens, Amazon crushes another legacy retailer

The American Customer Satisfaction Core Alpha ETF (ACSI) comprises about 170 mostly large-cap stocks that are selected according to American Customer Satisfaction Index scores. Stocks are allocated so that each sector is weighted within 10%, up or down, of that sector’s market-capitalization weighting in the benchmark S&P 500 Index (SPX)

As internet retail giant Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) expands into more businesses, pleasing customers may be the most important factor for companies looking to survive the onslaught.

When discussing fundamental stock research in an interview July 26, ACSI Funds chief strategist Kevin Quigg said financial results reported by companies “are in no way forward looking.” Measuring how people feel about companies “is a better forward indicator of future behavior and success,” he said.

Read: Amazon’s quarterly earnings plunge 77%

Before joining ACSI Funds a year ago, Quigg worked for State Street Corp. (STT) heading the SPDR ETFs’ global sales strategy, as well as its global capital markets and institutional ETF sales groups.

The American Customer Satisfaction Index was developed in 1994 by researchers at the University of Michigan, led by Claes Fornell, working with the American Society for Quality in Milwaukee, and CFI Group in Ann Arbor, Mich. Fornell is now the Distinguished Donald C. Cook Emeritus Professor of Business at the university.

The index measures the level of customer satisfaction of about 300 companies in 43 industries doing business in the U.S., based on surveys of about 180,000 people. Fornell is chairman of ACSI Funds.

The American Customer Satisfaction Core Alpha ETF was launched in November, and MarketWatch’s Ryan Vlastelica described the fund at that time after interviewing ACSI Funds CEO Phil Bak.

Soon after the fund was established, Apple Inc. (AAPL) was its largest holding, making up 3.4% of the portfolio, while Amazon accounted for only 0.4%. As of the stock market’s close July 26, Amazon was the biggest holding, representing 3.4% of the portfolio, with Apple second, at 3%, and Alphabet Inc.’s Class C shares (GOOG) in third place at 2.1%.

Quigg said Amazon had climbed to the top of the list because of “a few alterations to the methodology to better align our industries with investment industry norms,” and to give more weighting to companies with the highest levels of customer satisfaction in their industries.

Immune to Amazon?

Quigg disagreed with some of the conclusions by Jefferies Equity Research analysts who said in a report last week that the decline in stock prices for various competitors of Amazon had created some bargains for investors.

For example, Advance Auto Parts (AAP) is rated “buy” by Jefferies, and its stock is down 37% this year through July 26. But Quigg said competing auto-parts and accessories retailer AutoZone Inc. (AZO) which Jefferies rates “hold,” has a higher level of customer satisfaction — a score of 80 versus 79 for Advance Auto Parts. AutoZone has fallen a bit less this year, by 35%.

Another stock singled out as a bargain by the Jefferies team was Wal-Mart Stores Inc. (WMT) which Quigg called a “perennially low scorer.” Wal-Mart’s current ACSI score is 72, and “for reference,” Quigg said the score for Costco Wholesale Corp. (COST) is 83. Still, Wal-Mart’s stock is up 15.6% this year, and Costco is little changed.

The retail winner is Amazon — “perennially a leader,” he said. It’s currently at 86, up from 83 a year ago. Sure enough, the company’s stock has soared in 2017, by 40%, making CEO Jeff Bezos the world’s richest man (briefly) this week.

So the American Customer Satisfaction Index obviously can’t pick winners every time. Still, 18 of the ETF’s top 25 holdings have increased in value this year, two are little changed and five have declined. The biggest loser is U.S. Cellular Corp. (USM) down 13%.

Survival methods

Quigg voiced a mild objection to the notion that certain industries, including cruise lines, hotels and restaurants, might be immune to the Amazon effect. They are not immune to losing sales to competitors who provide superior service, he said.

Another point he made was that the internet provides hope for companies that are working hard to improve their customer service. JetBlue Airways Corp. (JBLU) is the only airline among the top 25 stocks held by the fund. There’s a perception that newer carriers provide better service than the major legacy carriers. However, since so much air-travel booking is done by people searching for the lowest prices online, the word could spread very quickly if customers become more satisfied with the way they are treated by a legacy carrier.

This quick spreading-of-the-word online could help other companies that are threatened by new technology or the Amazon effect make relatively speedy recoveries as their service quality improves.

Fund performance and holdings

The American Customer Satisfaction Core Alpha ETF had $29 million in assets as of July 26. It has returned 8% this year, which compares with a 12% return for the S&P 500 (SPX) Of course, a track record of less than a year is very little to go on when considering a long-term investment strategy.

item.title: A quarter of S&P 500’s 2017 climb due to five stocks (yes, those five)
item.dc:creator: Ryan Vlastelica
item.description: Throughout 2017, there’s one acronym that investors have in particular been sinking their teeth into: FAANG.
item.content:encoded:
THE TELL
By Ryan Vlastelica

The tech sector has provided more than 40% of the S&P 500’s advance

Throughout 2017, there’s one acronym that investors have in particular been sinking their teeth into: FAANG.

The term stands for a quintet of the market’s most pronounced highfliers: Facebook Inc. (FB) Apple Inc. (AAPL) Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) Netflix Inc. (NFLX) and Alphabet (GOOGL) the parent company of Google. Together they’ve accounted for a huge amount of the overall market’s advance, something that could leave major indexes vulnerable in the event the group turns lower.

Based on their Wednesday close, the FAANG stocks have accounted for more than a quarter of the S&P 500’s total year-to-date return (28.4%, to be exact), according to Howard Silverblatt, senior index analyst at S&P Dow Jones Indices. That calculation doesn’t include the sharp decline that several of the stocks underwent on Thursday.

Each of the five stocks is up sharply thus far this year, posting gains that range from about 20% to nearly 50%. Furthermore, four of the five are among the five largest stocks in the U.S. equity market, meaning they have an outsize weight on broader moves. Together, they account for more than 10% of the S&P 500 by market capitalization.

The benchmark S&P 500 (SPX) is up 10.6% thus far this year. The Nasdaq Composite Index (COMP) where all of the FAANG stocks trade, has climbed 18.6%. The Nasdaq -100 (NDX) which has an even more concentrated holding of the group, is up nearly 22%.

Overall, the information-technology sector has accounted for 41.6% of the S&P 500’s total return this year, per Silverblatt’s data, by far the most of any group. The tech sector (XLK) itself is up 18.9%, while the consumer-discretionary sector (XLY) —where Amazon and Netflix are classified, despite their connection to the tech industry—is up 13.1%.

The gains in these large-cap names have raised concerns about their valuation, with analysts noting similarities between the current market environment and the dot-com era, when there was a bubble in tech names that, when it burst, took down the broader market.

Related: Will tech rally continue? Hedge funds say yes, but mutual funds say no

Earlier this year, the largest exchange-traded fund to track the tech sector hit an all-time high on a total-return basis, recovering the ground it lost in the wake of the dot-com era.

On Thursday, an abrupt selloff in tech shares pressured the FAANG names (except for Facebook, which stayed higher in the wake of better-than-expected quarterly results), which in turn weighed on the overall market, pressuring the broader market and dragging the S&P 500 and Nasdaq to a close in negative territory.

item.title: Opinion: The Apple Car could run traditional automakers off the road
item.dc:creator: Vitaliy N. Katsenelson
item.description: Apple has an inside track to lead a radically new automobile industry, writes Vitaliy N. Katsenelson.
item.content:encoded:
OUTSIDE THE BOX
By Vitaliy N. Katsenelson

Apple's brand extends far beyond technology and coolness. The company has accumulated incredible goodwill with consumers.

So whenever Apple (AAPL) comes out with the Apple Car, it will grab a disproportionately large market share from General Motors (GM) and other automakers precisely because of that deep well of goodwill. By the time my youngest child, Mia Sarah, who is almost two, learns to drive, internal combustion engines will likely be a relic consigned to museums (just like Ford’s Model T).

I had this “Aha!” moment recently when I visited a Tesla (TSLA) store and saw its cars’ power train. It looks just like a skateboard — basically a flat slab of metal (which houses the battery), four wheels, and an electric engine the size of a large watermelon. That’s it — the Tesla has only 18 moving parts.

Wall Street nowadays is going gaga over the stocks of auto dealerships (especially after Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway bought Van Tuyl Group) and automakers. I am in the minority in thinking that party will come to an end. Just like Tesla, Apple is not going to be using a dealership model to sell its cars. Just as with the iPhone, the company will want complete control of the buying experience.

If both Tesla and Apple bypass the dealership model, the GMs of the world will be at an even larger competitive disadvantage. They will have to abandon the dealership model too. Yes, I know, selling cars directly to consumers is not legal in many states, but if the U.S. Constitution could be amended 27 times, the law on car sales (which is an artifact of the Great Depression) can be amended as well. The traditional dealership model is unlikely to survive anyway, as its economics dramatically degrade in the electric-car world. A car with few moving parts and minimal electronics has few things to break. Consequently, electric cars will need less servicing, throttling the dealerships’ most important profit center.

What is also amazing about electric cars is that they aren’t that much different from smartphones. Smartphone prices have declined significantly because their components became ubiquitous and commoditized. The simplicity of electric cars and the declining ambition of Tesla, Apple, and whoever else enters that space to be known as a “car” company will likely lead to commoditization of components and thus lower prices. Tesla today is more a software and battery company than a car company.

Think back to the day when Apple introduced the iPhone. No one suspected that it (and the smartphones that followed) would enable a service like Uber, which is putting cabdrivers worldwide out of business.

The baby boomer generation romanticizes cars. Most boomers can recite the horsepower and other engine specs of every car they have ever owned. For the tail end of Gen-X (my generation) and Millennials, a car is an interruption between Facebook (FB) and Twitter (TWTR) . We know the brand of speakers in our car but if asked would have to Google its horsepower. We feel little romanticism for our cars and have much higher brand loyalty to Apple and Google (GOOGL) than to GM or Ford Motor (F)

When Apple makes its entrance into the auto industry, it will likely be successful and highly disruptive. After all, Apple has the much-needed software know-how to design a car. (Apple is already working with car companies on CarPlay, the iPhone-centered car infotainment system.) Apple boasts a global network of stores, possesses unlimited resources ($150 billion of net cash and $50 billion of free cash flows annually), and its imagination has not been damaged by decades of producing cars with internal combustion engines.

General Motors’ answer to Tesla has been no different from Nokia’s response to the iPhone.

Let me stress that last point. There is a good reason why Nokia, which at one time was the dominant cellphone manufacturer, failed to compete with the iPhone. It had too much institutional knowledge. Nokia had hundreds of engineers who tried to add IQ to a dumb phone. The company was attempting to convert Symbian, a dumb-phone operating system, into a smartphone operating system. Despite Apple showing Nokia how the smartphone should look, the company couldn’t see its product as a smartphone but rather just as the next iteration of a dumb phone.

General Motors’ answer to Tesla has been no different from Nokia’s response to the iPhone. GM came out with the Chevy Volt, which was really one of its internal combustion engine (ICE) cars with an electric engine dumped in. Unless an ICE car company creates a silo unit isolated from the rest of the operation, it will be extremely difficult if not impossible to get engineers who have designed ICE vehicles all their lives to change their thinking and turn into electric-car engineers.

So, how does one invest in this overvalued market? Our strategy is spelled out in this fairly lengthy article.

Vitaliy N. Katsenelson is chief investment officer at Investment Management Associates in Denver, Colo.,and which holds a position in Apple. He is the author of “Active Value Investing” (Wiley) and “The Little Book of Sideways Markets” (Wiley). This article first appeared on Katsenelson’s Contrarian Edge blog.

item.title: Trump: Apple’s Tim Cook is promising a major stateside manufacturing push
item.dc:creator: Tim Rostan
item.description: Trump’s revelation: that he’s been in ongoing contact with Apple CEO Tim Cook and that Cook is making big — actually big, big, big — plans to onshore at least a portion of the Silicon Valley pioneer’s manufacturing.
item.content:encoded:
KEY WORDS
By Tim Rostan

‘Big, big, big’

In a Wall Street Journal interview published Tuesday afternoon, President Donald Trump continued his idiosyncratic campaign to run down his own attorney general, Jeff Sessions, who was the first member of the U.S. Senate to endorse Trump’s candidacy for the White House.

First Take: The one person who might be able to save Jeff Sessions hasn’t tried

The new-new news in the Journal interview was that Trump is now “looking at” firing Sessions. But equally juicy, viewed through a MarketWatch lens, was Trump’s reported revelation that he’s been in ongoing contact with Apple (AAPL) CEO Tim Cook and that Cook is making big — actually big, big, big — plans to onshore at least a portion of his company’s manufacturing:

‘I spoke to [Cook]. He’s promised me three big plants — big, big, big. I said you know, Tim, unless you start building your plants in this country, I won’t consider my administration an economic success. He called me, and he said they are going forward.’ Trump on Apple CEO Tim Cook

Apple, according to the Journal, declined an opportunity to comment.

For more than a decade, the bulk of all Apple manufacturing has taken place in China, much of it through the well-known subcontractor Foxconn though, according to a Journal timeline compiled in 2012, it had earlier employed thousands of American workers to build its computers in states including California and Texas.

item.description: Taiwan’s Foxconn Technology Group, which assembles Apple Inc.’s iPhones, is nearing a decision to invest in Wisconsin and could hold an event in Washington, D.C., as soon as this week to discuss U.S. investment plans, people familiar with the matter said.
item.content:encoded:
THE WALL STREET JOURNAL
By Yoko Kubota, Takashi Mochizuki

Detroit area also marked for a possible plant

Taiwan’s Foxconn Technology Group, which assembles Apple Inc.’s iPhones, is nearing a decision to invest in Wisconsin and could hold an event in Washington, D.C., as soon as this week to discuss U.S. investment plans, people familiar with the matter said.

In Wisconsin, Foxconn (TW:2354) (AAPL) is looking at producing display panels that can be used in large-screen televisions, three people briefed on the plans said.

The investment, if confirmed, would be the latest by Asian manufacturers in the U.S. as President Donald Trump seeks to revive manufacturing there.

Foxconn, formally known as Hon Hai Precision Industry Co., has said publicly that it is looking at seven states in the U.S., where it would invest a total of $10 billion or more to manufacture flat-panel screens and related equipment. In June, a company executive identified the seven as Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Texas and Wisconsin.

In addition to Wisconsin, Foxconn is looking in the Detroit area for a possible plant, two people familiar with the plans said. It wasn’t clear what that plant would make.

item.title: Two-thirds of U.S. investors think stocks are overvalued
item.dc:creator: Ryan Vlastelica
item.description: Major U.S. stock-market indexes are trading near record levels, and more investors are finding that troubling.
item.content:encoded:
MARKET EXTRA
By Ryan Vlastelica

Tech and consumer discretionary stocks particularly singled out as pricey

Major U.S. stock-market indexes are trading near records, and more investors are finding that unsettling.

About 36% of investment managers find the U.S. stock market undervalued or fairly valued at current levels, according to a quarterly investment manager survey performed by Northern Trust Asset Management. That’s the lowest reading in the history of the survey, which began in the third quarter of 2008.

Nearly two-thirds of investors—65%—say the U.S. equity market is overvalued, the highest percentage on record.

The survey was conducted over a period that ended June 22. The S&P 500 (SPX) is up 1.5% since then.

Concerns have been growing over the valuation of the U.S. market, which by one estimation is the priciest on the planet. However, the picture isn’t completely bearish. The market’s recent gains have occurred against a backdrop of improving corporate earnings, a strong labor market, and positive—albeit tepid—economic growth.

“Although managers view U.S. equity valuations as extended, fundamentals—GDP growth, low inflation and earnings growth—are still favorable,” Christopher Vella, chief investment officer for multi-manager solutions at Northern Trust Asset Management said in a news release.

The survey indicated that 60% of respondents expect U.S. economic growth to remain stable in the near-term future, though only 29% expect it to accelerate, down from the 44% maintaining that view in the previous survey. As far as positioning goes, 33% of managers surveyed became more risk averse over the past quarter, an above-average level, while only 4% became less risk averse, compared with 14% in the previous survey. More than 60% of managers polled didn’t change their portfolio’s risk profile over the past quarter, and 82% reported cash levels that were unchanged from the first quarter.

Read: Tug of war between bulls and bears is keeping the stock market in check

Experts have recently been encouraging investors to look overseas for the next leg higher, and that view held in Northern Trust’s survey. While only 36% of managers view the U.S. as undervalued, 86% feel that way about European stocks, and 88% view emerging market equities as undervalued or fairly valued.

The S&P 500 has hit a series of records thus far in 2017, and it is up more than 10% on the year. A good chunk of the gains—and a big reason that there are general concerns over valuation—have come on the so-called FAANG stocks, a group that includes the technology stocks Facebook (FB) Apple (AAPL) and Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) as well as the consumer discretionary names Amazon.com (AMZN) and Netflix Inc. (NFLX)

These names implicitly came up in the survey, as only 6% of respondents considered consumer staples undervalued, while 15% said the same of technology. A much higher percentage thought there was further room to grow in both financial stocks, where 39% said the group was undervalued, as well as energy and health care, sectors where 32% said they were cheap or fairly valued.

The divergence between the market’s most and least expensive is unusually high, and that can cloud the outlook for the broader market. According to the Boston Company, an asset manager, the difference in the price-to-book ratios—one measure of equity valuations—for the market’s most-expensive and least-expensive quintile is around 10, an unusually high level.

That divergence indicates there are values to be had outside of the trading favorites that have been seeing meteoric growth of late.

“There’s a real big opportunity to invest in those deeper value oriented companies. A lot of stocks look very expensive to us, even the ones that have great growth, because the market doesn’t believe we’ll have a cyclical upturn [in economic activity], so the market has been gravitating to them,” said John Bailer, senior portfolio manager at the Boston Company. “I think we’re setting ourselves up for a market that’s just OK over the next five years.”

item.title: Opinion: Don’t fall for the biggest misconception about the FAANG stocks
item.dc:creator: Howard Gold
item.description: Investors say this time is different than the dot-com era. Howard Gold says don’t be so sure.
item.content:encoded:
HOWARD GOLD'S NO-NONSENSE INVESTING
By Howard Gold

The biggest winners of the dot-com era — until they weren’t — also were mainstream tech companies making gobs of money

Every time I write a column about the high-flying FAANG stocks, especially when I compare them with the internet bubble of the late 1990s, I get the same response from Kool-Aid-drinking readers: These companies make lots of money; the dot-coms didn’t, so there’s a reason these stocks can keep going higher.

Aside from being a variation on the old theme, “this time is different,” this argument for Facebook (FB) Amazon (AMZN) Apple (AAPL) Netflix (NFLX) and Google (whose parent is Alphabet (GOOG) (GOOGL) ) has the additional virtue of being spectacularly wrong.

Investors who have short memories may be thinking of the most egregious failures of that benighted era: Kozmo.com and Webvan, TheGlobe.com and eToys, and, most notorious of all, Pets.com.

But those companies, which were indeed huge money losers, had minuscule market caps; they couldn’t remotely drive the Nasdaq Composite Index (COMP) down 72% from its March 2000 peak to its bear-market low. In March 2000, the Nasdaq had more than 4,700 stocks with a combined market value of $6.6 trillion.

No, the biggest winners of the dot-com era were mainstream technology companies making gobs of money. I dug up old annual reports and 10-K statements on some of the best performers and found that although some superstars like Micron Technology were in the red in 1999, the overwhelming majority were very profitable with powerful earnings growth.

It also didn’t hurt that real GDP grew at almost 5% in 1999 and unemployment was near 4% or that companies were upgrading their systems like crazy to protect against the much-feared Y2K software bug.

Still, that didn’t save them from the terrible rout that followed; some of the biggest names and best performers lost even more than the Nasdaq did, whose collapse rivaled that of the Dow Jones Industrial Average in the 1930s or Japan’s Nikkei index in the 1990s. Since then, many of these former supernovas have been bought out, and very, very few are priced higher now than they were in March 2000, a long 17 years ago.

The tables below tell the story. The first, which I compiled using historical stock data (which wasn’t readily available for all the stocks I wanted to look at) and past 10-K filings, shows the rise and subsequent fall of some of that era’s most prominent technology names. All five were among the 10 largest Nasdaq stocks by market value at the peak. In fact, Microsoft and Cisco Systems were valedictorian and salutatorian of that ill-fated class of 2000.

I calculated their rise from the low stock price in 1997-1998, before the final phase of dot-com mania kicked in, to their peak, mostly in 2000, then traced the extent of their decline in the subsequent bear market, which lasted until March 2003, when the Iraq war began. (I used historical data from Yahoo Finance, which adjusts share prices for stock splits.)

The last column shows their growth in earnings per share from 1998 to 1999, which was stunning. It ranged from 48% for Cisco to 180% for Applied Materials—hardly “unprofitable” by any measure.

Looking at their earnings growth at the time, investors could plausibly claim—as they do today with Netflix and Facebook—that these were great growth companies that had “cracked the code” on technological innovation and had the numbers to prove it. And yet only Microsoft and Oracle now trade above their 2000 peaks.

Taking a longer view, Matt Krantz of USA Today in 2009 looked at the very best performers of the 1990s and traced how they did in the 2000s. I used his stock numbers, then dug out the 1999 and 2000 10-Ks I could find, and voilà! Again, most of these companies were huge money makers whose rise was extraordinary but whose fall was catastrophic.

So, where are they now? Mostly, as gone as the wife in that best-selling thriller from a few years ago:

•Oracle bought Sun Microsystems in 2010.

•Novellus Systems was acquired by Lam Research in 2011.

•Tellabs agreed to a private-equity buyout in 2013.

•BMC Software was bought out by private-equity firms in 2013 for $6.9 billion in cash.

•In 2015 Dell and its private-equity partners agreed to buy EMC for $67 billion, or $33 a share, at the time the largest acquisition in tech history.

Incidentally, almost all of these stocks ended up much lower than they were at their peak in 1999-2000.

As for the FAANGs, they have easily beaten the S&P 500 this year. The worst among them, Alphabet, has gained 23% as of this week, more than doubling the S&P’s (SPX) 2017 advance.

But the lessons of the dot-com era are clear: Even big earnings growth doesn’t inoculate high-flying stocks against precipitate collapses; in fact, the very best companies can fall the most when the bear starts to growl.

And with some FAANG stocks trading at nosebleed valuations, investors should be extremely wary of throwing money at these shares in the hope that they will keep growing right to the sky.

Howard R. Gold is a MarketWatch columnist and founder and editor of GoldenEgg Investing, which offers exclusive market commentary and simple, low-cost, low-risk retirement investing plans. Follow him on Twitter @howardrgold.

item.title: Apple’s stock climbs to 7th straight gain after analyst boosts price target
item.dc:creator: Tomi Kilgore
item.description: Apple’s stock rallies to a seventh-straight gain, the win streak in nine months, after Morgan Stanley raised its price target.
item.content:encoded:
THE RATINGS GAME
By Tomi Kilgore

Apple stock’s win streak would be longest so far this year

Shares of Apple Inc. rose to a seventh straight gain Monday, after Morgan Stanley boosted its price target on the belief that bad news for this year could be great news for next year.

The stock (AAPL) rose as much as 1.2% in intraday trade before paring gains to close up 52 cents, or 0.3%, at $149.56 The current win streak is now the longest such stretch since the seven-day streak ended Oct. 12, 2016.

The stock’s percentage gain was the fifth-biggest among the Dow Jones Industrial Average’s components, while the price gain added about points to the price of the Dow (DJIA) which fell 8 points. See Market Snapshot.

Analyst Katy Huberty at Morgan Stanley raised her stock price target to $182, which is 22% above current levels, and 12% above the average price target -- $162.12 -- of the 44 analysts surveyed by FactSet. Huberty’s new target is now the third highest of those surveyed, behind the $202 target of Drexel Hamilton’s Brian White and the $184 target of BTIG’s Walter Piecyk, according to FactSet.

The bad news is that when Apple reports fiscal third-quarter results on Aug. 1, Huberty expects the technology behemoth to provide a fourth-quarter outlook that is below Wall Street’s consensus, because Huberty expects the new iPhone be shipped slightly later than typical, in October rather than September.

Don’t miss: IPhone production issues reportedly threaten Apple sales rebound.

See also: The iPhone at 10: This is how much the 2007 original will cost you on eBay.

But the potential great news is that should drive fiscal 2018 estimates higher, and its “creates a dynamic of much better-than-normal December- and March-quarter seasonality,” Huberty wrote in a note to clients.

Huberty said her new earnings-per-share estimate for fiscal 2018, which starts in October, is 11% above the consensus, while her revenue outlook is 13% above consensus.

Apple is currently expected to report EPS for the quarter ended in June of $1.57, and report September quarter EPS of $1.86, according to FactSet. The fiscal 2018 FactSet EPS consensus is $10.50.

The stock has rallied 4.8% during its current seven-day win streak, matching the gain during the October win streak.

It has run up 29.1% year to date, while the tech-heavy Nadsaq 100 Index (NDX) has climbed 20.1% and the Dow has gained 9.4%.

item.title: Hedge fund manager who scored a 78% annual return with Apple and Amazon is short-selling Netflix
item.dc:creator: Philip van Doorn
item.description: Trip Miller of Gullane Capital says the TV- and movie-streaming company’s time is running out.
item.content:encoded:
DEEP DIVE
By Philip van Doorn

Trip Miller of Gullane Capital says the TV- and movie-streaming company’s time is running out

Richard “Trip” Miller of Gullane Capital LLC, whose hedge fund generated a 78% return after fees last year, is still bullish on Apple Inc. and Amazon.com Inc. because the tech companies’ massive cash flow enables them to easily enter new industries in search of profits.

Still, Miller isn’t a fan of all so-called FAANG stocks: He has a short position on Netflix Inc., betting on a decline in the shares. (FAANG stands for Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Netflix and Google.)

Miller founded Gullane Capital of Memphis, Tenn., in 2002. The firm runs $24 million in its hedge fund, Gullane Capital Partners LLC, as well as another $68 million in private accounts following the same strategy as the fund. He said all employees place their entire investible assets in the fund to align their interests with those of clients.

The fund follows a value strategy, with a stated goal of purchasing stocks at 50% of its “appraisal,” buying more shares as prices fall, and selling as prices approach Miller’s value estimate. The fund typically has 10 to 20 long positions, but also has five to 15 short positions. For long positions, Miller said the fund seeks to hold positions for many years, “with very low turnover.”

Gullane Capital Partners LLC had a 77.5% return during 2016, after fees, according to Convergex. The fee structure is modeled on Warren Buffett’s for the partnership he ran from 1956 to 1969: a combination of 1% of assets under management annually, plus 20% of any gains for the fund over a 6% return in a given year; if returns amount to less than 6%, investors pay only the 1% annual fee.

Over the past three years, through Dec. 31, the fund’s average annual return, after fees, was 12.3%, compared with 8.9% for the S&P 500 Index (SPX) For the past five years, the fund’s average annual return after fees was 11.3%, trailing the S&P 500’s 14.7% gain.

History won’t repeat

Miller said it was important to “temper expectations” after such a strong performance in 2016, when all 18 of the fund’s long positions were up (if reinvested dividends were included).

“We don’t expect that to happen again. I think it was the byproduct of planting the seeds in 2015 and being wrong in the fourth quarter of 2015,” he said, referring to his purchases of Wynn Resorts Ltd. shares. The fund was down 28% in 2015.

Miller said he bought Wynn “too early,” but that the trade — then and now the fund’s largest position — worked out very well in 2016, when it rose 28%, and in 2017, when it was up 55% through July 7. This is the third time Miller’s team has invested in the casino operator.

Miller said he is willing to invest in companies over and over.

“We know when they are cheap, and we know when they are fully valued,” he said.

He said it is a continual “struggle” to avoid buying or selling too early.

“We’re never going to be great at calling bottoms,” he said.

Here are Miller’s thoughts about six of the fund’s long positions and two of its short positions:

Long positions

Chesapeake Energy: Shares of Chesapeake Energy Corp. (CHK) are down 35% this year, through July 7, after returning 56% last year, when they greatly boosted the fund’s performance.

Miller said that even though the company has been doing “a marvelous job” reducing debt, it is “more leveraged than any other company we own or have ever owned.” He still believes Chesapeake is a good long-term investment because “the assets they have in the ground exceed those liabilities multifold.”

Apple: Miller ties in Apple (AAPL) with Google and Amazon, saying high levels of free cash flow enable those companies to move into various businesses that investors may not anticipate, “many of which are home runs.”

Miller agrees with Apple skeptics, who see plenty of risk from the company’s reliance on one product, the iPhone. But he sees a silver lining in the company’s services business. Apple’s services revenue for its fiscal second quarter rose 18% from a year earlier. Miller believes the company’s services business — including the distribution of iPhone apps, music and video — “has the potential over the next three years to become 20% to 25% of revenue for Apple.” He also sees long-term potential for the company in the networking of all sorts of appliances and equipment in homes.

Amazon: “We have owned it for over a decade and have opportunistically added to our position over time,” Miller said. The last time he bought “materially” more shares of Amazon.com (AMZN) was in February 2016, following a heavy sell-off of the broader market.

Miller admires Amazon’s willingness to “probe and buy things” to enter new businesses. “If it works, wonderful. If it doesn’t work out, if they do not get the returns they want, they shut it down.”

Disney: Walt Disney Co.’s (DIS) shares are flat this year, with dividends reinvested, following a 1% return in 2016. When discussing investors’ concerns over the company’s ESPN subsidiary, Miller said, there continues to be “high demand” for ESPN’s product, but that Disney needs to figure out how to distribute its sports content in an increasingly fragmented media environment.

For the long term, Miller is confident in Disney because of its size and quality. “Could I build a similar company with $20 billion? The answer is no,” he said.

Miller said the company’s bottom line will be improved by its growing cruise ship business and its deal to take greater control of Euro Disney.

FedEx: Miller is impressed that Frederick W. Smith, the founder of FedEx Corp. (FDX) is still its CEO, “with a lot of skin in the game.” He said that even though the stock is near its all-time high, its valuation is relatively low. The stock trades for 14 times the consensus 2018 earnings estimate, among analysts polled by FactSet, compared with a forward price-to-earnings ratio of 16.6 for the S&P 500.

He expects great things from the company’s integration of the Netherlands-based TNT Express, which it acquired in May.

McDonald’s: “We bought it for the second time a couple of years ago when it was trading below $90 a share,” at a time when it seemed consumers’ focus on healthier food would hurt McDonald’s, Miller said. The company’s “poor management” was pushing “a bad strategy” on franchisees, he said.

Shares of McDonald’s Corp. (MCD) closed at $156.27 on July 10. Miller said Steve Easterbrook, who took over as the company’s CEO in March 2015, “has done a magnificent job turning around a big ship.”

He said the company had “done a pretty good job pivoting to the consumer. It is much healthier than it was even a few years ago.” But he also said he “would not buy more here” in light of the shares’ price increase.

Short positions

Miller attributed a great part of the fund’s success in 2016 on its short positions in retail stocks, as well as apparel and “hardline goods.”

Even with all the pessimism about brick-and-mortar retailers in a world transformed by Amazon and other online retailers, Miller’s outlook for the industry is unusually grim.

“We have a bias that over the next 25 years, 70% of the mall-based apparel or hardline [retailers] will go out of business,” he said. He cited Kirkland’s Inc. (KIRK) and Tuesday Morning Corp. (TUES) as former short trades that had worked over the past year.

Miller went into greater detail about two non-retail short positions:

Netflix: Shares of Netflix (NFLX) are up 21% this year, following an 8% return last year. But the ride hasn’t been smooth:

Miller said he had shorted Netflix at “a blended $114” a share in November and December 2015, and then covered at about $90 a share in July of last year.

“Then I made a short-term stupid error shorting Netflix at over $100 a share in the fall of last year,” he said. The shares closed at $150.18 on July 7.

Miller said eventual market saturation in the U.S., low barriers to entry for competitors and a cash burn rate of $1.5 billion a year would all work against Netflix’s shares eventually.

“At the end of the day, you can spend a lot of money but you need to get a return on it. It doesn’t make any sense the way it is being valued, at all,” he said.

Royal Caribbean: Miller has shorted and covered Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd. (RCL) before. This year he shorted the stock at $110. The shares closed at $109.20 on July 7.

“During Royal Caribbean’s 25 years as a public company, it has had cumulative negative free cash flow,” Miller said. “The maintenance and growth capex [capital expenditures] that they have to spend basically leaves them with nothing,” he said.

item.title: Nasdaq-100 ETF sees heavy inflows amid five-day rally
item.dc:creator: Ryan Vlastelica
item.description: The most widely used exchange-traded fund to track the Nasdaq-100 has seen massive inflows in recent sessions, a sign that investors are moving back into the index as large-cap internet and technology shares continue to recover from a recent bout of weakness.
item.content:encoded:
ETF FOCUS
By Ryan Vlastelica

Assets have jumped by more than $4 billion over the past week

The most widely used exchange-traded fund to track the Nasdaq-100 has seen massive inflows in recent sessions, a sign that investors are moving back into the index as large-cap internet and technology shares continue to recover from a recent bout of weakness.

Over the past day and week, the PowerShares QQQ Trust (QQQ) has seen the biggest inflows of any ETF by far, according to FactSet data. More than $1.1 billion poured into the fund over the past session, bringing its inflows over the past week to $4.35 billion.

By comparison, the fund with the second-highest inflows over the past day—the Vanguard FTSE Developed Markets ETF (VEA) —has inflows of $123.5 million. The weekly inflows were more than twice the fund with the second-highest creations, the iShares Core MSCI EAFE (IEFA) which had $1.9 billion in inflows.

The influx of investor attention has brought the ETF’s assets up to $51.45 billion, up from a recent low of $47.38 billion on July 5.

Those inflows have come alongside strong gains for the fund, which is on track for its fifth straight daily advance, having risen 3.7% over that period. Thus far this year, it is up more than 19%.

Despite those gains, recent trading has been turbulent. The fund is heavily weighted toward the so-called FAANG stocks, which stands for Facebook (FB) Apple (AAPL) Amazon (AMZN) Netflix (NFLX) and Alphabet (GOOGL) the parent company of Google; these stocks comprise more than a third of the portfolio. This group has also driven broad-market moves of late, first by falling sharply on concerns they have become overdone, and then rebounding.

That translated to sharp daily moves for the fund, and heavy trading. More than 1 billion shares exchanged hands in the fund over the course of June, compared with 580 million over June 2016.

item.title: Opinion: Apple is bullying stock market investors
item.dc:creator: Simon Maierhofer
item.description: The iPhone maker accounts for a large weighting in major indices, says Simon Maierhofer.
item.content:encoded:
By Simon Maierhofer

The iPhone maker accounts for a large weighting in major indices

Who is bullying the U.S. stock market?

It’s popular to say that Goldman Sachs, J.P. Morgan Chase, the PPT (Plunge Protection Team) or the Federal Reserve, because all engage in shenanigans we’ll never fully know.

But they don’t bully the stock market. Apple does.

Omnipresent Apple

Apple Inc. (AAPL) is one of three stocks racing to become the first trillion-dollar company. Unlike Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) and Alphabet Inc. (GOOG) (the other two contenders), Apple is the only stock to be included in all three of the following: the Nasdaq 100 Index (NDX) the S&P 500 Index (SPX) and the Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA)

In fact, Apple is more than just included — it rules the roost. It is the biggest component of the Nasdaq 100 (11.6%), the S&P 500 (3.6%) and the Dow Jones Industrial Average (4.6%).

At one point, Apple was up as much as 35% this year and accounted for 10% to 20% of the 2017 returns of the S&P 500 or Dow Jones Industrial Average.

Apple is truly the big dog of the U.S. stock market. When the stock coughs, U.S. indices catch a cold.

Support and resistance

Buying or owning the Nasdaq (and, by extension, the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average) without knowing what’s going on with Apple is like planning a Caribbean vacation without knowing when hurricane season is.

For those who don’t have the time to keep up with projections for the iPhone, iPad and other product sales or read the tea levels on whether earnings will disappoint or not, and then project how Wall Street may react, here is a simple but effective way to assess Apple:

The chart below shows some basic support and resistance levels. In mid-May, Apple ran into black trend channel resistance and peeled back.

This trend channel is one reason why we considered the short-term upside potential for Apple, the Nasdaq and S&P 500 to be limited.

According to the May 21 Profit Radar Report: “The Nasdaq 100 may be close to where the S&P 500 was in December 2016 and March 2017: at peak momentum. Stocks almost never (permanently) top at peak momentum. Therefore, the Nasdaq 100 appears to be close to a correctional period somewhat similar to what the S&P experienced since March 1.”

Support for Apple is around $140 and $135. Currently, Apple is floating in a “technical vacuum,” above support and below resistance.

Stock seasonality

Apple has been on a 13-year tear, so seasonality is overall bullish. There are, however, a few seasonal weak spots, one of them in mid-July.

Seasonality for individual stocks is not a critically important factor, but it is something to keep in mind.

Summary

At the current price of around $145, Apple is above support and below resistance. A move to $135-$140 would bring Apple closer to a buy signal, while a move to $160 (or higher) would increase downside risk considerably.

Interestingly, the S&P 500, just like Apple, is in limbo now. Once the S&P 500 snaps out of its range, it is likely to follow the roadmap drawn by the most powerful market indicators.

Simon Maierhofer is the founder of iSPYETF.

item.title: iPhone production issues reportedly threaten Apple sales rebound
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Huston
item.description: Apple Inc. is reportedly running into issues developing its expected iPhone 8, which could hurt the “super cycle” analysts expected in the fall.
item.content:encoded:
By Caitlin Huston

Apple could delay shipments of new iPhones amid fingerprint sensor concerns, analysts say, which would push sales into next fiscal year

Apple Inc. is reportedly running into issues building its next iPhone, which could hurt the “super cycle” analysts expected in the fall to push the company’s biggest moneymaker back to sales growth.

According to multiple analyst notes this week, Apple (AAPL) is running into issues with the fingerprint sensor, which the company has been looking to upgrade on the new iPhone. Analysts believe Apple will either delay shipments, which would presumably affect fourth-quarter financial results, or deliver the phones without the fingerprint sensor, which could hurt company unit sales and overall sales mix.

Apple has been expected to launch a new iPhone cycle in September, with three new phones including a new superpremium model with an organic light-emitting diode, or OLED, screen and 3-D sensing capability. With that phone, Apple was rumored to be moving its “Touch ID” function, which currently uses a fingerprint sensor in the home button, to underneath the screen, thus eliminating the home button.

Don’t miss: Apple bets that you’ll adopt these three tech habits

That’s where the development issues are reportedly coming in, as Andy Hargreaves, an analyst at KeyBanc Capital Markets, wrote that Apple is seeing “poor performance” through the glass. If it is not able to fix it before August, Apple may have to give up on the fingerprint technology in favor of facial recognition. But that’s not ideal.

“While this is possible, we do not view it as attractive as it would create usability risk and would likely require shipping without initial qualification for Apple Pay, both of which could hurt unit sales and sales mix,” Hargreaves wrote.

Hargreaves added that continuing to work with third-party engineers on the fingerprint sensor, after it appears that Apple may have given up on one major technology investment, means that Apple’s gross margin may be damaged.

On rumors of delays, Goldman Sachs analysts estimate three possible shipment dates of Sept. 22, Sept. 29 and October, with their revenue guidance estimates declining from $51 billion to $53 billion at the earliest launch to less than $48 billion in October, when there would be zero selling days in the fourth quarter.

See also: Apple accepts reality, but can it take AR and VR to the mainstream?

Apple iPhone unit sales declined for the first time last year, and the company likely needs a big launch late in its fiscal year to avoid declining sales for a second year in a row. Chief Executive Tim Cook admitted in May that iPhone sales were suffering a “pause” as consumers wait for the next iPhone model, which led to disappointing revenue guidance for Apple’s fiscal third quarter.

Apple is scheduled to report results for the third quarter on Aug. 1, and would be expected to issue revenue guidance for the fourth quarter then that could give more clues about how it sees the iPhone launch. Apple typically unveils new iPhones in stand-alone events in September, but has not scheduled that annual showcase yet.

Raymond James analysts wrote earlier this month that they see a delayed launch for the superpremium iPhone by one month, and an on-time launch for the other models. Apple will likely have supply issues with the more expensive iPhone for a few months following the launch, the analysts said.

Other analysts have predicted that the launch of the new iPhone will usher in another “super cycle” for Apple, as Apple’s large consumer base has pent-up demand for a new, innovative phone. Goldman Sachs analysts say consumers do not appear to be scared off by the premium iPhone’s predicted $999 price tag. In an independent survey of 1,000 U.S. consumers, they found that 28% indicated an interest in buying an iPhone in the fall, up from 25% in April.

See also: A key Apple sales metric may decline during the iPhone super cycle

But demand is still not what it could be, according to Goldman Sachs. The analysts estimate that Apple now has an installed base of close to 700 million users, which is more than twice the size of its estimated base at the time of its last super cycle in 2014 with the iPhone 6.

But even with this larger base of users, the analysts predict only 5% unit-sales growth compared with the iPhone 6 cycle, as the improved number of iPhone users looking to upgrade is offset by declining demand from first-time smartphone buyers and a decline in those users looking to switch from Alphabet Inc.’s (GOOGL) (GOOG) Android competitor. This percentage could increase, the analysts said, if the new iPhone cycle is a more “meaningful refresh” than they anticipated.

Shares of Apple were down less than 1% Wednesday morning. Apple shares have gained 2.6% in the past three months, underperforming the S&P 500 index (SPX) , which increased 4% in that time period, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) , which counts Apple as a component and has gained 4.4%.

item.title: Apple will build a Chinese data center following a new cybersecurity law
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Abkowitz
Eva Dou
item.description: Apple will be storing data for Chinese customers with a government-owned company, a major concession by the company.
item.content:encoded:
THE WALL STREET JOURNAL
By Alyssa Abkowitz, Eva Dou

Apple increasingly faces regulatory challenges in China

To comply with tough new cybersecurity rules, Apple will for the first time begin storing data for its customers in China with a government-owned company—a move that means relinquishing some control over its Chinese data.

Apple (AAPL) will build its first Chinese data center in the southern province of Guizhou to house data for customers of its iCloud service. The data include photos, documents, apps and videos uploaded by Apple users throughout the mainland, the company said Wednesday.

The center will be operated by a company owned by the Guizhou provincial government, and whose chairman was a local government official until last year.

Under the agreement, Apple will retain control over encryption keys at the data center. It wasn’t clear if it would have access to any of the data itself, which would be overseen by its Guizhou partner.

item.title: Apple’s iTunes fast losing market share in video
item.dc:creator: Ben Fritz
Tripp Mickle
item.description: Apple Inc.’s iTunes Store — already struggling against rising competition for music listeners — is losing the battle for video viewers as well.
item.content:encoded:
THE WALL STREET JOURNAL
By Ben Fritz , Tripp Mickle

Despite rise in video sales and rentals, competitors are making a big dent

Apple Inc.’s iTunes Store — already struggling against rising competition for music listeners — is losing the battle for video viewers as well.

The company’s market share for renting and selling movies has been falling for several years, tumbling to between 20% and 35% from well over 50% as recently as 2012, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

No third parties track market share in the digital-movie business, making exact figures impossible to obtain. Different Hollywood studios do different amounts of business with Apple, but several of them report a marked decline in iTunes’ leadership position.

An Apple spokeswoman, who didn’t dispute the market-share estimates, said Apple (AAPL) is focused on providing customers with video content across subscription services such as Netflix (NFLX) and Time Warner Inc.’s (TWX) HBO, as well as iTunes, where she said movie purchases and rentals have increased over the past year and hit their highest level in more than a decade. Apple’s growth appears to be a consequence of overall industry increases, despite its market-share losses. Last year, total U.S. digital-movie sales and rentals rose a combined 12% to $5.3 billion in the U.S., according to PricewaterhouseCoopers.

item.title: Apple’s HomePod and Apple Watch are in demand, analysts say
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Huston
item.description: Interest in Apple Inc.’s newest products, including the HomePod smart speaker, appears to be picking up, which could help the company gain a competitive advantage over Amazon Inc. in the sector.
item.content:encoded:
By Caitlin Huston

Raymond James analysts see increasing demand in Apple’s other products while expecting flat iPhone sales for second quarter

Interest in Apple Inc.’s newest products, including the HomePod smart speaker, appears to be picking up, which could help the company gain a competitive advantage over Amazon Inc. in the sector.

According to a Raymond James survey of 500 consumers in June, about 14% of iPhone owners intend to buy Apple’s (AAPL) HomePod, which, combined with those who intend to buy a Beats wireless speaker, surpasses the demand for the Amazon (AMZN) Echo. There is also high demand for the Apple Watch and AirPods, Apple’s wireless headphones, which could contribute more to the company’s bottom line as iPhone sales flatten.

Apple unveiled its HomePod at its developer conference in June, but consumers won’t be able to buy it until December. The HomePod is similar in function to Amazon’s Echo -- though it’s billed as more of a smart speaker rather than a smart assistant -- but comes in at a higher price of $349 vs. $180 for the Echo.

See also: Apple bets that you’ll adopt these three tech habits

The report showed that 19% of consumers surveyed intend to purchase an Apple speaker, which includes iPhone users who intend to buy the Beats wireless speaker. That figure beats the 16% of consumers who intend to buy an Amazon Echo, or a related product such as the Tap or Dot. It also helps Apple surpass Bose, which had 18% of iPhone owners intending to buy its Bluetooth speaker.

Demand is also increasing for the Apple Watch, with the 12% of consumers indicating they would buy the watch, the highest level the analysts have seen so far. It approaches demand for Fitbit Inc. (FIT) , which was at 12%. And while the analysts do not have numbers on AirPods, they say the demand has been greater than the supply for six months.

While the category including these three products makes up only about 5% of Apple’s overall revenue, the analysts said the company could continue to grow for years in this category due to the large addressable market in wearables.

“Last quarter, driven by strong y/y trends for Apple Watch and high demand for AirPods, the category grew 31% y/y, and we suspect similar growth is likely the next several quarters,” Tavis McCourt, the lead analyst on the report, wrote in the note.

This may be important as Apple has seen flattening revenue and declines in the number of iPhones sold. At its June developer conference, Apple also made a push into augmented reality with the intent of being a leader in the space and eventually gaining more young consumers.

Apple has also been seeing gains in its software and services revenue, made up of iTunes, the Apple Store, iCloud, Apple Care and Apple Pay, and it was one of the few segments to grow in 2016. The Raymond James analysts expect to grow about 20% year-over-year when Apple reports its second-quarter earnings later this month.

Still, while waiting for a new iPhone cycle, analysts said they expect year-over-year iPhone sales to be “flattish” for the second quarter.

Consumers appear to be waiting for the expected iPhone 7s or iPhone with an OLED screen, both rumored to come in the fall, as the analysts’ consumer survey found that an increasing percentage of consumers plan to upgrade in the next 12 months, but not within the next three months.

Other analysts have said they expect the expected launch of Apple’s iPhone 8 in September to trigger a “super cycle,” in which consumers upgrade to the new phones leading to a record 2018 of iPhone sales.

The Raymond James analysts said they expect the iPhone 7s to have an on-time launch, while the OLED phones may be delayed. They expect iPhone units sales of 40 million for June and 45 million for September. The FactSet consensus is for 41 million units in June and 47 million in September.

They maintained their outperform rating and $163 price target. The average rating on FactSet is overweight with a $161.63 price target.

Shares of Apple have fallen 7.5% in the past month, compared with the Dow Jones Industrial Average’s (DJIA) 0.7% gain and the S&P 500’s (SPX) loss of 0.5%.

item.title: Opinion: These 8 threats to the stock market’s eerie calm should make you worried
item.dc:creator: Michael Brush
item.description: What to do when volatility hits your stock portfolio.
item.content:encoded:
By Michael Brush

What to do when volatility hits your stock portfolio

While the political world has been in a state of panic since Donald Trump's election, the stock market has experienced the exact opposite. Investors have been remarkably calm — almost weirdly so. Until recently, virtually every trading day this year has brought smallish market moves of less than a percentage point. It's gotten downright boring.

"We haven't had a 5% correction in the last 250 days or so," says Baird investment strategist William Delwiche, reflecting the longest patch of this kind of calm since the mid 1990s. This year's first-half peak-to-trough move in the S&P 500

(SPX) was the smallest since 1995 and the second-smallest on record, he says.

All of this is about to change. After all, if there is one sure thing about the market, it's that trends eventually revert to the mean, says Mark Zandi, chief economist at Moody’s Analytics. Here are eight reasons why this will happen with volatility — possibly soon — and what you should do to prepare now.

1. The market's ‘season of the witch’ is around the corner

Historically, August is the most volatile month for stocks, says Doug Ramsey, chief investment officer of The Leuthold Group, and co-portfolio manager of its Leuthold Core Investment Fund (LCORX) .

This makes sense, because September and October often bring the biggest declines. Investors know this. So the August volatility could be bull vs. bear jockeying ahead of expected seasonal weakness.

2. Investors are too complacent

Investor complacency is now "deep-seated and widespread," says Baird chief investment strategist Bruce Bittles. He cites robust cash flows into stocks, and sentiment measures revealing broad confidence.

This might feel good if you are in stocks. But it is actually dangerous. Overly-confident investors are more likely to be shocked by negative news, as in "Gee who saw that coming?!" This makes them more likely to sell, when it happens.

3. A change of the guard at the top

Much of the 2017 market advance can be traced to the solid performance of a few mega-cap darlings. Think Amazon.com (AMZN) , Apple (AAPL) Facebook (FB) , Alphabet (GOOGL) and Netflix (NFLX) . All of that changed in early June when these stocks cracked. "As the market sorts through who will be in the next leadership group, that adds opportunity for volatility," says Baird’s Delwiche.

Read: Does Tesla’s plunge signal the end for growth stocks?

4. The baby boomers are programmed to mess things up

Boomers get blamed for a lot of things. So why not market volatility? Here's the logic: Many boomers aren't prepared for retirement. Returns on cash and bonds have been excruciatingly low. So boomers have piled into stocks relative to prior generations, points out Zandi. You can see where this is going. Fearful of the proverbial cat food retirement diet, they'll pull money from stocks quickly on any decline. The upshot: Any downside stock moves will get amplified.

5. All that hatin' on ‘Wall Street banks’ is coming back to bite you

Regulatory reform since the financial crisis, notably the Volcker Rule, has forced the big banks to get rid of broker-dealer divisions and related trading desks. With fewer institutions making markets, there's less liquidity, and trading is thinner, says Zandi. This, too, will amplify declines when volatility strikes. Don't count on high frequency traders to pick up the slack. We all know they vanish from the market once big sell orders appear. Can you say "flash crash?"

6. Heightened geopolitical risks could boil over at any moment

North Korea now regularly tests missiles that can reach Alaska. ISIS-inspired terror attacks are all too common. China is flexing its muscles in the waters off its coastline. European voters are rebelling against the European Union. The list of hot spots goes on and on. Underlying it all is the rolling U.S. political drama. "Trump is a real wild card," says Mark DeVaul, equity portfolio manager of the Hennessy Equity and Income Fund (HEIIX) .

7. Fed doubters may be in for a big surprise

Confident that growth is on track, Fed members boldly expect three rate hikes this year, three next year, and three in 2019. But a lot of investors aren't buying it. Like Pavlov's dogs, they've been trained to doubt bullish Fed expectations about economic growth. Doing so has rewarded investors betting against robust growth — as signs of weaker-than-expected growth inevitably re-emerged.

Now, eurodollar and Fed funds futures markets suggest investors once again question the Fed's growth forecasts. Investors expect far fewer Fed rate hikes than the Fed does. "This probably reflects a view that the economy’s long-run growth potential has declined a lot since the crisis," says Zandi.

Like the Fed, though, Zandi disagrees with the nabobs of negativism on this one. Someone is wrong, and therein lies the potential for volatility. "If we and the Fed are right, which seems increasingly likely given the 4.3% unemployment rate that is quickly headed lower, investors will be sorely disappointed." This will upset the markets.

8. The market is developing a troubling split-personality

In his seminal investing book “Stock Market Logic: A Sophisticated Approach to Profits on Wall Street,” first published in 1970s, Norman Fosback describes a useful market indicator he calls the "High Low Logic Index." This indicator is deceptively simple to calculate. It's just the lesser of the following two data points for a given index: The percentage of new lows, and the percentage of new highs.

When this number is high, it tells us that both the new lows and new highs are elevated. This is a sign of market divergence, which can be an early warning sign of greater volatility ahead. "As the indices make new highs, you want to see most stocks participating," says Leuthold’s Ramsey, who brought this wonky indicator to my attention. Or as Fosback originally wrote: "A healthy market requires some semblance of internal uniformity."

What's this indicator telling us now? Since 1998, readings above 6% on the Nasdaq have presaged significant market weakness, says Ramsey. It was recently close, at 5.5%. (Like Fosback, Ramsey uses moving averages in his calculations, to smooth out the volatility in these numbers.)

What to do now

"It would be prudent to prepare for a bumpy ride," concludes Zandi. But how? Three suggestions:

1. If you are a long-term investor, which is probably the best approach for most people, then do nothing — other than prepare yourself psychologically to ride it out. Whatever happens that scares most investors out of stocks will be pretty scary, otherwise they wouldn't sell. So it might frighten you, too. Don't let it.

2. If you are more of a trader, get out of dubious trades now. Get off margin. Have buying power for sharp declines in your favorite names.

3. Consider buying portfolio insurance. Tom Clarke, co-manager of William Blair Macro Allocation Fund (WMCNX) has been purchasing put options, which go up in value when markets decline. Put options are cheap right now because of that eerily low volatility. "It's one of the things that scares us," says Clarke. "It definitely reverts to the mean at some point."

At the time of publication, Michael Brush had no positions in any stocks mentioned in this column. Brush suggested AMZN, GOOGL, FB and NFLX in his stock newsletter several years ago.

item.title: Here’s a chart of the most valuable brands in the world... notice anything?
item.dc:creator: Sue Chang
item.description: The world’s No. 1 brand by value is a U.S. tech company. So are No. 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6.
item.content:encoded:
MARKET EXTRA
By Sue Chang

The world’s No. 1 brand by value is a U.S. tech company. So are No. 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6.

U.S. tech stocks may be under pressure lately, but they are still the top dogs when it comes to brand power.

The latest ranking from WPP’s Kantar Millward Brown shows that the elites of the most valuable brands in the world are mostly tech companies, and overwhelmingly American.

For the second year in a row, Google (GOOG) (GOOGL) is the most valuable brand with a price tag of $245.6 billion, followed by Apple Inc. (AAPL) with $234.7 billion, and Microsoft Corp. (MSFT) at $143.2 billion. Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) jumped to fourth with its value soaring 41% to $139.3 billion, while Facebook Inc. (FB) retained the fifth spot for a second year with $129.8 billion and AT&T Inc. (T) fell two notches to sixth, with a value of $115.1 billion.

Visa Inc. (V) was seventh with $111 billion and Tencent Holdings Ltd. (HK:0700) , a Chinese internet company and the first non-U.S. name to make the top 10 list since 2013, jostled its way to eighth with $102.1 billion. Silicon Valley pioneer IBM (IBM) traded places with McDonald’s Corp. (MCD) moving up to ninth with $102.1 billion while the fast-food giant slipped to 10th with $97.7 billion.

In contrast to other surveys, which measure a brand value based on a single criteria such as market capitalization, the research firm uses several metrics for its list, including a company’s ability to persuade a consumer to choose its product and pay a premium for it.

In 2017, the cumulative value of the top 100 brands grew 8% year-over-year to $3.6 trillion, and their stocks surged 124.9% between April 2006 and April 2017, far outstripping both the S&P 500 (SPX) and the MSCI World Index during the same period, according to Kantar Millward Brown.

In a testament to America’s soft power and economic influence, U.S. companies claimed more than half of the top 100 spots, with 54, accounting for 71% of the list’s value.

Technology firms, including telecom providers and e-commerce companies, clearly dominated the list, checking in with 37 brands for 54% of the list’s total value. In fact, Apple and Google, the two most expensive names in the world, are together worth as much as Sweden’s economy, while the seven newcomers this year are all tech related — YouTube, Hewlett Packard Enterprise Co. (HPE) Salesforce.com Inc. (CRM) Netflix Inc. (NFLX) Snapchat (SNAP) Xfinity (CMCSA) and Sprint Corp. (S)

There is also a generational shift. Top brands are getting younger, with the average age of the big 10 falling to 42 years, from 88 in 2006.

Only three brands have survived the ravages of time. In 2006, the top 10 were Microsoft, General Electric Co. (GE) Coke (KO) China Mobile Ltd. (HK:0941) , Marlboro (PM) Walmart (WMT) Google, IBM, Citigroup Inc. (C) and Toyota Motor Corp. (TM)

“The evolution of the BrandZ Global Top 10 over the past 12 years reflects the dominance of technology and the disruptive impact of the global financial crisis, technological innovation and changing consumer attitudes about health,” said Kantar Millward Brown in its report.

Indeed, the landscape is likely to further change in the coming years, with values of brands like Tesla Inc. (TSLA) ($5.88 billion) and Morgan Stanley (MS) ($8.92 billion) surging through the ranks.

item.title: Samsung set to surpass Apple as the world’s most profitable tech company
item.dc:creator: Jacky Wong
item.description: Samsung Electronics likely edged past Apple to become the world’s most profitable technology company last quarter. But to continue the strong run, it may hope the iPhone maker does better as well.
item.content:encoded:
THE WALL STREET JOURNAL
By Jacky Wong

Samsung’s profit drivers include the Galaxy S8 phone

Samsung Electronics likely edged past Apple to become the world’s most profitable technology company last quarter. But to continue the strong run, it may hope the iPhone maker does better as well.

The South Korean tech giant (KR:005930) said Friday it expects its operating profit for the quarter ended June to be a record 14 trillion won ($12.1 billion)—a 72% jump from a year earlier. On the other hand, (AAPL) will likely report an operating profit of $10.6 billion for its latest quarter when it announces results next month, according to estimates from S&P Global Market Intelligence.

Rising memory chip prices, driven by strong demand from servers and mobile, have likely contributed to Samsung’s strong results—the company hasn’t provided many details at this point. About 60% of its operating profit comes from the semiconductor business, according to Morgan Stanley. The March launch of its new flagship phone, the Galaxy S8, has also helped. Apple, on the other hand, continues to see slowing iPhone sales.
