item.title: Finance sites erroneously show Amazon, Apple, other stocks crashing
item.dc:creator: Mike Murphy
item.description: Incorrect stock data on Google Finance and Yahoo Finance appeared to be freaking out some investors Monday evening
item.content:encoded:
By Mike Murphy

Test data from Nasdaq apparently mistakenly put onto live sites

No, Amazon and Apple stock did not crash Monday. And if you held Mattel stock, you’re not suddenly rich.

But incorrect stock data on the popular Google Finance, Yahoo Finance and Bloomberg sites appeared to be freaking out some investors Monday evening, after test data was apparently misinterpreted by third-party providers to those sites.

As of 11 p.m. Eastern, Google Finance said Amazon.com Inc. shares were down more than 87%, to $123.47. Previously, Yahoo Finance said Amazon was down 74%, to $248.49. In reality, Amazon (AMZN) finished the day down 1.5%, at $953.66, and was up 0.1% in after-hours trading, according to FactSet.

Apple Inc. shares were similarly skewed, with both Google and Yahoo Finance saying they were down 14%, also to $123.47. Actually, Apple (AAPL) ended the day down just 0.4%, at $143.50, according to FactSet, and was up slightly in after-hours trading.

$123.47 — or amounts close to that — appeared to be the common denominator for the test data, wildly skewing some stocks down to that level while others skyrocketed up to it. For example, the test data sent eBay Inc. (EBAY) soaring 253%, Mattel Inc. (MAT) skyrocketing 473% and Microsoft Corp. (MSFT) up 79%.

Page views to MarketWatch’s stock pages — which remained accurate — soared as investors double-checked exactly what was going on Monday evening.

A spokesman for Nasdaq put the blame on third-party data providers.

“As part of its normal process, the UTP distributed test data and certain third parties improperly propagated the data. Nasdaq is working with third-party vendors to resolve the matter,” a Nasdaq spokesman said late Monday.

The spokesman speculated that the day’s early close might have caused confusion with some closing prices for a number of third parties, including Bloomberg and Yahoo, but emphasized that no trades were affected by the erroneous quotes.

Yahoo Finance and Bloomberg appeared to be showing correct ticker data as of 11 p.m. Eastern, but Google Finance was still showing the test data.

Google’s website says Swiss-based SIX Financial Information provides end-of-day prices, and New York-based Interactive Data Real-Time Services, Inc. provides intra-day prices. Interactive Data Real-Time Services’ parent company, Intercontinental Exchange, did not immediately respond for comment.

A Google spokesperson confirmed vie email that its third-party data service provided inaccurate information which it had received from Nasdaq, while a SIX spokesman said his company wasn’t at fault.

“We checked with our data team — our data is correct and in no way corrupted,” the SIX spokesman said in an email.

Victor Reklaitis in London contributed to this report.

item.title: Opinion: Alphabet’s Waymo is winning the race for self-driving cars — and Apple is far behind
item.dc:creator: Jeff Reeves
item.description: Baidu and Tesla are also speeding ahead, says Jeff Reeves.
item.content:encoded:
JEFF REEVES'S STRENGTH IN NUMBERS
By Jeff Reeves

Baidu and Tesla are also speeding ahead, while Daimler is one to watch

Self-driving cars have always been a subject of popular debate among consumers and investors alike. But lately, the technology — and the profit potential — has started to feel very real.

This week, shares of Avis Budget Group Inc. (CAR) surged after Alphabet Inc. (GOOG) (GOOGL) announced it will partner with the company to support and maintenance its fast-growing fleet of self-driving vehicles. Avis gets a regular paycheck for its services in the multiyear deal, and Alphabet’s Waymo arm gets access to thousands of vehicles and millions of potential customers in its effort to move forward with its autonomous driving dreams.

Waymo is way ahead of the curve in this emerging field, having recently announced its fleet has logged more than 3 million miles on public roads. Its adorable “Firefly” almost single-handedly brought self-driving cars out of sci-fi pages and into reality in 2014, and it has remained at the front of the field ever since.

The laggards in the field, meanwhile, are still just testing their tech in labs and controlled settings.

Out of all the self-driving players in the world, Alphabet (also Google’s parent) seems like a clear No. 1 to me. But who is speeding toward a self-driving future to challenge them? And who is disappointing investors and falling behind, destined to be left in the dust?

Here’s a rundown of some of the other major players in the autonomous driving space right now, and what their outlook is:

Speeding ahead

Baidu

China tech giant Baidu Inc. ADR (BIDU) is often called the “Google of China” by investors. The company has lived up to that moniker not just through its internet dominance, but also by a push into autonomous vehicles.

Baidu won approval from California to test its self-driving cars at the end of 2016, in addition to older projects under way in China since as early as 2014. The company claims to be working on mass-production capabilities of its technology that will be ready for large-scale launch by 2020, according to its website, and is already partnering with auto manufacturers and insurance companies to achieve those ends. And given Baidu’s recent announcement that it is making its self-driving software open source — just like the Android smartphone operating system that powered Google’s mobile unit a decade ago — that goal doesn’t seem unrealistic.

Tesla

For me, Tesla Inc. (TSLA) became the de facto leader in self-driving technology in 2016 after “Bill’s Mom” became an internet sensation by freaking out in the driver’s seat of a Model S on Autopilot. And with its self-driving hardware including cameras and sensors coming standard on every model it produces, Tesla clearly is diving headfirst into the future of self-driving cars.

To be clear, Autopilot is still only semiautonomous — as tragically evidenced by a recent fatal crash where the driver was warned seven times to put his hands on the wheel but didn’t take back control. But unlike competitors that are experimenting with self-driving technology at a small scale or in controlled settings, Tesla is perhaps the company closest to a real-world rollout of truly autonomous driving technology since it is a one-stop shop and can largely go it alone.

Read: What happened when I turned on Tesla’s autopilot

Cruising along

Honda

While plenty of tech giants are trying to get in on autonomous cars, don’t think all traditional auto makers are just waiting to be bailed out by Silicon Valley. Honda Motor Co. (HMC) (JP:7267) began testing self-driving cars at a mothballed San Francisco military base back in 2015, and in 2016 semiautonomous technology including lane assist and forward collision warnings came standard in every luxury vehicle sold under Honda’s Acura nameplate.

The company recently said it is committed to achieving “Level 4” autonomous driving by 2025, or where onboard systems can handle the majority of driving situations without human intervention. It’s later than some of the forerunners, yes, but Honda seems to be placing a priority on caution and safety in this emerging field. That may prevent it from being first, but may ensure it has the right tech when its solutions come to market.

Daimler

Most consumers think of a self-driving electric sedan when they think of what technology can offer. But Mercedes-Benz manufacturer Daimler AG (DDAIF) (DE:DAI) has a much bigger plan. Late last year, the company took an autonomous 18-wheeler on the open road — a tremendous feat for its Highway Pilot technology. What’s equally impressive is that the big rig wasn’t built to be autonomous, but was simply fitted with the necessary software and hardware.

The consumer market may be larger and perhaps more lucrative, but don’t discount the potential of being a player in the world of autonomous freight and logistics. Daimler said its gear could be ready for prime time by 2020, presuming the legal framework is in place for such technology. That could be a game changer for businesses as well as individual drivers.

Falling behind

Apple

While Apple Inc. (AAPL) isn’t quite as far along as Google in its self-driving-car efforts, the company did announce this week that it will partner with Hertz Global Holdings Inc. (HTZ) to test autonomous technology of its own. But details showthe deal is for a measly few SUVs, hardly an impressive ramp to the half-dozen other vehicles Apple has been testing in California for the past year.

While there has long been speculation on an Apple Car under the code name Project Titan, it has become increasingly clear that the tech giant is more focused on artificial intelligence and software, despite its hardware roots. Costly overhead and a lack of tangible results have caused some investors to question whether Apple will ever deliver, and investors who have already been biting their nails over the high-stakes iPhone launch this year may not want to give Tim Cook & Co. leeway on this project for much longer.

Uber

Early backers of yet-to-IPO Uber have long seen the promise of self-driving taxis. But the high hopes of previous years has given way to more sordid dramas and practical challenges that are making innovation in 2017 more difficult. That includes the ouster of CEO Travis Kalanick amid allegations of sexual misconduct at the highest levels of the company, but it also includes the bottom-line practicalities of increased competition from competitors like Lyft that have stepped up recently.

Read: Uber must raise fares — and do 5 more things — to survive

For a young company like Uber that’s still bleeding cash, it’s risky to plow money aggressively into self-driving cars even as it still trying to assert its dominance in the nascent arena of ride sharing. Adding fuel to the fire is a late-2016 rollout of autonomous driving tests in Pittsburgh that soured in a hurry, leaving local politicians and community leaders questioning the wisdom of continuing the experiment.

Uber may have a lot of smart people and a good launchpad for self-driving cars, but it also has some serious challenges that it needs to sort out before it worries about where autonomous driving technology will be in a decade’s time.

item.title: 5 ways the iPhone changed the world
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Malito
item.description: For better and, sometimes for worse, Apple’s blockbuster revolutionized society.
item.content:encoded:
By Alessandra Malito

For better and, sometimes for worse, Apple’s blockbuster revolutionized society

Many Americans have a love-hate relationship with their iPhone.

Ten years ago this month, when late Apple (AAPL) co-founder Steve Jobs announced the release of the first generation iPhone, he said it was like having “your life in your pocket,” but in the decade since, the smartphone has truly taken on a life of its own. Today, smartphones don’t just connect to the web, they have millions of apps for people to use for any type of activity, such as sports, cooking, purchasing goods, organizing, traveling and money management.

See: This is how much the 2007 original will cost you on eBay

Millennials in particular may be addicted to their smartphones. Almost four in 10 young Americans interact with their phones more than they do with their significant others, families, friends and coworkers, according to a Bank of America study done last year. About 77% of millennials own a smartphone, and spend at least two hours a day on them. Smartphone usage is distracting, especially at work or at dinner, and can be dangerous, such as when driving or trying to get a good night’s rest.

Here are five unique results of the iPhone’s release:

How you find a partner and date

Matchmaking has gone mobile with apps like Bumble and Tinder and, some say, hook-ups and Starbucks-loving online daters have killed the dinner date. While just 5% of married or committed Americans say they met their significant other online, this type of dating has surged for people of all ages, according to Pew Research data. Today, 27% of people 18 to 24 years old use online dating, up from 10% in 2013, and 12% of 55 to 64 year olds use online dating, compared with 6% in 2013.

See also: How swiping right on Tinder helps NBA teams win more games on the road

Of course, not everyone uses these apps for sex or love. Some singletons just want to know they’ve still got it. And other, more devout iPhone users may not even consider a date with someone who uses another type of smartphone, such as the Android.

You’re always being watched

Today, almost everyone has the potential of being watched — or caught — when they’re doing something wrong. Short videos shot on a smartphone can easily go viral, and knowing that keeps people on their toes, but also may make them less creative or increase their stress levels. A few bad cases? The New York Mets mascot, Mr. Met, was caught on camera flipping the bird at a fan. (The person in the suit won’t be returning as the beloved mascot, though the individual was not fired, the team said.) Others have lost jobs after being recorded acting inappropriately, on or off the job. Worse, there are also apps to keep track of children, but are also used to catch cheating spouses.

Don’t miss: A $151,000 Trump iPhone

Who talks on the phone anymore?

Phones, ironically, aren’t always used to make calls. Americans prefer texting over talking on the phone, according to a 2015 International Smartphone Mobility Report, which found smartphone users receive five times as many texts versus phone calls each day, and spend 26 minutes texting versus six minutes talking. However, texting can derail concentration and work. It takes people 20 minutes to fully return to the task they were doing before checking their phones, this recent study found. Texting and tweeting at work is also a no-no in some workplaces. Aside from emergency situations, phone calls are still important for family members, doctors, financial professionals, lawyers and soon-to-be exes.

iPhones killed the compact disc

Forget iPods and CD players. With the iPhone, music streaming took off, creating a new set of challenges for the music industry. For the first time in a decade, streaming dominated the music industry’s revenue last year, and there are more than 22 million subscribers in the U.S. listening to tens of millions of songs every day. That’s more than the number of people who subscribe to cable TV. Music streaming may even go beyond the iPhone, as futurist and Tesla (TSLA) Chief Executive Officer Elon Musk hinted at another streaming service for Tesla cars to add to the ranks of companies like Spotify, Apple, Pandora and Jay Z’s Tidal.

Never get lost or get stuck at a dinner party

In the years since smartphones have become popular, so too have the accessibility of maps and tracking systems such as the GPS (global positioning system), even when the phone is off. Directions aren’t always accurate, but having a GPS comes in handy when you’re on the road and unsure of where to go. By 2019, the number of GPS-enabling apps will double, according to Greg Milner, author of “PinPoint,” the book about these systems. Companies are even beginning to create indoor GPS, which could help consumers in shopping malls. Map apps are constantly updating, too. Google Maps, for example, added the ability to make restaurant reservations in 2014 and updated the aesthetics of its service last year to highlight hot spots in various neighborhoods.

item.title: ‘Baby Driver’ is driven by its music, but can the soundtrack hang with the best?
item.dc:creator: Trey Williams
item.description: “Baby Driver” is a action crime thriller set in a world where music drives every action. The film stars Ansel Elgort as Baby, a young getaway driver who’s constantly listening to music to drown out the hum in ears from tinnitus.
item.content:encoded:
By Trey Williams

Hollywood’s best-selling soundtrack of all time is Whitney Houston’s ‘The Bodyguard’

Great music in film can alert audiences to a secret about a character that they might not otherwise discover. Music in movies can portray joy, depression. It can foreshadow a character’s fate, and in some cases, including in the just-released “Baby Driver,” it might carry the fate of the entire film.

One of Hollywood’s most prolific composers, Hans Zimmer has said: “If you talk to any director, they’ll say music is 50% of the movie.”

There’s a library of classic films that use music as such a consequential part of the story that the two are linked forever, ingrained in the pages of the popular culture zeitgeist: “Don’t You (Forget About Me)” to close out “The Breakfast Club,” “Dirty Dancing’s” “(I’ve Had) The Time of My Life,” “Rocky” and “Eye of the Tiger” and Whitney Houston’s “I Will Always Love You” in “The Bodyguard.”

In Edgar Wright’s newest film “Baby Driver,” in theaters this weekend, one could argue the music has a starring role. It wouldn’t be a surprise if it had its own trailer on the lot.

But can the film carve out a place in movie music history?

“Baby Driver” is a action crime thriller where music drives every action. The film stars Ansel Elgort as Baby, a young getaway driver with a talent for flair, even in tasks as simple as making sandwiches. Baby has tinnitus, so he’s constantly listening to music to drown out the hum.

The soundtrack is the baseline to “Baby Driver” and what prompted the film. Variety aptly called it a music nerd’s dream. And in a conversation with the publication, Wright said the Jon Spencer Blues Explosion song “Bellbottoms,” which kicks off the 27-song soundtrack and first heist of the film, inspired the idea for the film.

Check out: The Tupac movie illustrates why biopics about musicians can be difficult

Also see: Hollywood is running out of hit ’80s movies to reboot

“I would listen to that song and imagine this car chase,” he told Variety. “The idea that started it all off was: Maybe a getaway driver is listening to this song, and he’s actually trying to time out his getaways and literally have the perfect score for the perfect score.”

So it’s no surprise that Sony Pictures (SNE) is heavily pushing the film’s soundtrack, and that it’s nearly all anyone who has seen the movie can talk about.

Read: Motion Pictures Academy continues diversity push, inviting Dwayne Johnson, Gal Gadot and Barry Jenkins

“A big conversation around this film is: ‘Wow you have to go see this movie because the use of music in this movie is incredible,’” said ComScore media analyst Paul Dergarabedian. “That could really help sustain the movie and the soundtrack.”

The film is expected to pull in a $20.5 million return on its $34.0 million production budget in its opening weekend, according to estimates from analysts at Box Office. The film has already pulled in $9 million in box office receipts.

The soundtrack, released on CD, vinyl and digital platforms such as Apple Music (AAPL) and Spotify, via Sony’s (SNE) record label Columbia Records. As audiences fall for the music Wright curated for the film, it will be interesting to track the popularity and success of the soundtrack.

The best-selling soundtrack of all time, according to numbers from 2016, is Whitney Houston’s “The Bodyguard.” It sold 17 million units. The second best is “Saturday Night Fever” with 15 million units, followed by “Purple Rain,” which sold 13 million units. All of the top six soundtracks sold at least 10 million albums.

As much of a hit as “Baby Driver” and its music has been so far, however, it isn’t likely to land among the best-sold soundtracks. One reason is the way people buy and listen to music now.

Don’t miss: ‘Wonder Woman’ passes ‘Mamma Mia!’ as highest-grossing film by female director

“The music [in “Baby Driver”] is so integral to the movie and its entire through-line,” Dergarabedian said. “I would put it in my top five movie soundtracks of all time, but it may not be up there in terms of sales.

“Nowadays people can just find that one song they loved and cherry pick.”

In the time of “The Big Chill,” or a little later, “The Bodyguard,” if audiences fell in love with a film’s soundtrack they would have to buy the album. All of it.

“They didn’t really sell singles for soundtracks,” Dergarabedian said. “You used to have to buy the whole album. The studios loved it.”

item.title: The iPhone at 10: This is how much the 2007 original will cost you on eBay
item.dc:creator: Quentin Fottrell
item.description: 10 years later some people are still holding onto their original iPhones.
item.content:encoded:
By Quentin Fottrell

10 years later some people are still holding onto their original iPhones

The iPhone is 10. How the world has changed because of it. But there are some people who have held onto their original version.

Some first edition iPhones are more valuable than others. Bob Kraft, a retired business owner in Madison, Wisc., received an offer of $11,000 for an unopened iPhone that came in a factory gift box from Apple with a red ribbon — and he turned it down. His asking price was $15,000. “That was tempting,” he says. “But I’m not in a hurry to sell it.” He’s one of at least a dozen sellers of the 2007 iPhone who is hoping to make hay from the 10th anniversary of the iconic smartphone. He has discounted the phone from $18,000, the price he first listed it for on eBay about five months ago. He’s hoping a collector will see value in the original. “If you open it, it’s only worth a couple of bucks.”

The iPhone first went on sale on June 29, 2007. Some people have held onto it because they’re sentimental, while others are hoping to make thousands of dollars from their unopened first edition. Jobs announced that he would reinvent the phone and, despite skepticism from his rivals and stiff competition from BlackBerry (CA:BB) Apple’s (AAPL) co-founder and former chief executive — who died in 2011 — created a multi-billion-dollar blockbuster. “An iPod, a phone, and an internet communicator,” Jobs said at his 2007 presentation. “These are not three separate devices, this is one device.” He added, “What we want do is make a leapfrog product that is way smarter than any mobile device has ever been, and super-easy to use.”

‘I do still have my original iPhone and it’s still in great working condition. It will always hold a special place in my heart.’ —Brant DeBow, executive vice president of technology for BiTE interactive

Sarah Jacobs, an associate visual features editor, refuses to recycle her 2007 iPhone and was using it up until just a couple of years ago. “Even though I’ve recycled every other iPhone I’ve owned, there’s something about the original that keeps me hanging on as though one day it might be worth money.” And it is — at least, that’s what collectors are hoping. The original, unopened 2007 iPhone is selling for anything from $3,500 to $20,000 on eBay (EBAY) Contrast this with owners of used 2007 iPhones. They sell for a meager 75 cents (and resell for a paltry $1.25) and, Morgan MacArthur, chief technology officer at price-comparison company Flipsy, says there’s no demand for them. (Apple did not respond to request for comment on the resale market for the original iPhone or sales of iPhone 7.)

Don’t miss: Meet Amazon’s first customer

Ten years is a long time in smartphone technology. The first generation iPhone, which cost $499 for a 4-gigabtye model and $599 for an 8-gigabyte model, was a major upgrade for people using flip phones. Those flips could text, email and access the internet, but not do much more than that. The 2007 iPhone also has a shorter battery life, less sophisticated camera, is not hot-wired for the faster 4G wireless networks, does not play many new apps and does not have Siri, the voice-activated search engine. And yet some folk are unwilling to part with it. “I do, in fact, still have my original iPhone and it’s still in great working condition,” says Brant DeBow, executive vice president of technology for BiTE interactive. “It will always hold a special place in my heart because it was the phone that kicked off our company.” (His company makes apps.) He recently bought an iPhone 7, although his favorite video game is only available on his 2007 version.

Also see: There are two reasons (and only two) to buy the iPhone 7

The superlatives Apple uses for each phone are only matched by the upgrades. Last year, Philip Schiller, Apple’s senior vice president of worldwide marketing, said, “iPhone 7 and iPhone 7 Plus dramatically improve every aspect of the iPhone experience, reaching a new level of innovation and precision to make this the best iPhone we have ever made.” Sound familiar? In 2013, he hailed the iPhone 5S as “the most forward-thinking phone we have ever created.” He said as much about the iPhone 5: “Never before have we built a product with this extraordinary level of fit and finish.” Before that, the iPhone 4S was called “the most amazing iPhone yet.” And before that, the iPhone 4 was, to quote Jobs, “the most beautiful thing we have ever made.”

But upgrading to older models and slower growth in the iPhone 6S has caused a slowdown in Apple revenue, analysts say. Last May, Apple Chief Executive Tim Cook made a rare acknowledgment that customers were delaying iPhone purchases serves as a warning that iPhone sales could continue to lag for a second straight year. Kevin Rieffel, an attorney who lives near Philadelphia, is one customer who still has his original 2007 iPhone in a desk drawer, but has so far resisted the lure of the iPhone 7. “I’ve upgraded at least once since 2014 to the 64GB iPhone 6 Plus,” he says. “I’m partial to the bigger screen, faster wireless data and better battery life.”

For Apple aficionados like Rieffel, the 2007 iPhone may not be the smartest or fastest, but it’s still the best.

item.title: Google’s stock is still ‘compelling,’ says outperforming tech fund manager
item.dc:creator: Philip van Doorn
item.description: Google parent Alphabet is the top holding of the Red Oak Technology Select Fund.
item.content:encoded:
DEEP DIVE
By Philip van Doorn

Google parent Alphabet is the top holding of the Red Oak Technology Select Fund

How would you react to a 39% gain in a particular stock over the past 12 months? Would you suggest selling it to lock in the gain?

Mark Oelschlager, the portfolio manager for the Red Oak Technology Select Fund (ROGSX) doesn’t think this way at all, and he has a very solid track record standing behind his continued faith in Alphabet, Google’s parent company.

Despite that 39% increase in both Alphabet Inc.‘s Class A (GOOGL) and Class C (GOOG) shares, Oelschlager described both stocks as still “compelling.” He cited Alphabet’s 17% increase in first-quarter revenue and said, “the stock is right around a 5% free cash yield, which is roughly where the market is and might even be better.”

A company’s free cash flow is its remaining cash flow after capital-spending commitments. This is money that can be used for any corporate purpose, including acquisitions or other expansion. If you divide a company’s annual free cash flow per share by its share price, you have the free cash flow yield, which can be used for comparison

The two Alphabet share classes together made up 8.1% of the Red Oak Technology Select Fund as of March 31, by far the fund’s largest equity position.

The fund was ranked 17th of 7,581 actively managed open-ended mutual fund, based on average total returns for five years, through June 26, according to data provided by Morningstar. It has $460 million in assets and was established in December 1998. Oelschlager, who is Oak Associates Funds’ co-chief investment officer, took over as the fund’s portfolio manager in April 2006. Before joining Oak Associates in 2000, he was an equity analyst for the State Teachers Retirement System of Ohio.

Here’s how the fund’s performance has stacked up against its peer group, according to Morningstar, as well as the S&P 500 technology sector and the Guggenheim S&P 500 Equal Weight Technology ETF (RYT) through June 27:

S&P 500 Information Technology Sector 41.3% 17.8% 10.7% 10.7%
Guggenheim S&P 500 Equal Weight Technology ETF 41.3% 21.0% 9.7% N/A
Sources: Morningstar, FactSet

Oelschlager attributed a great part of the fund’s success to its focus on the technology sector. But it stands out even among its peers. Among 51 actively managed U.S.open-ended technology funds — which excludes narrowly focused funds, such as those that only buy semiconductor stocks, for example — the Red Oak Technology Select Fund ranked third over the past five years.

Also see: No. 1 mutual fund, which made a killing off Amazon and Tesla, is now focused on these stocks

Oelschlager said free cash flow yield and price-to-earnings valuations are important parts of his team’s stock selection, but that he also is concerned with the “sustainability” of a business.“

Many tech investors “think they need to find the big stars of the future,” he told MarketWatch in a June 28 interview, but the odds of identifying the next Google or Facebook “are against you.”

“When you focus on companies growing the fastest, the deck again is stacked against you because of high valuations,” he added.

Another stock Oelschlager is keen on is KLA-Tencor Corp. (KLAC) which makes equipment for the semiconductor industry. Valuation is the reason: free cash flow is about 6% and the shares trade for 15.9 times the consensus 2018 earnings estimate among analysts polled by FactSet. That compares with a forward price-to-earnings ratio of 17.1 for the S&P 500 information technology sector and of 16.5 for the entire S&P 500 index (SPX)

KLA-Tencor’s valuation looked especially low because it “dominates” its industry niche, he said. “Granted, it is a cyclical, and does not necessarily deserve a high multiple, but they have proven to be fairly consistent and the stock looks like a good long-term investment,” he added.

One position Oelschlager has “cut back quite a bit” is chip maker Nvidia Inc. (NVDA) after it returned 227% during 2016.

Low turnover

According to Morningstar, the fund’s annual turnover ratio has been 6%, which is amazingly low for an actively managed fund. This underscores Oelschlager’s style of sticking with companies showing consistently high rates of growth.

“A lot of people are tempted to trade a lot, because it feels like you are accomplishing something by constantly making moves. But often times, the best thing is to do nothing,” he said.

However, the fund will be much more active during periods of disruption in the market, he said. During 2009, for example, the fund’s turnover was 30%. That was in the wake of the credit crisis that sent the S&P 500 information technology sector down 43% in 2008.

item.title: Goldman gets more optimistic about economy, but still sees rocky end to 2017
item.dc:creator: Ryan Vlastelica
item.description: Goldman Sachs is coming around on the economy’s prospects, though it isn’t quite bullish.
item.content:encoded:
MARKET EXTRA
By Ryan Vlastelica

Goldman’s raised S&P 500 target to 2,400 implies a slight dip from current levels

Goldman Sachs is coming around on the economy’s prospects, though it isn’t quite bullish.

The investment bank, which has for months been warning that U.S. stock market gains have occurred against a backdrop of falling earnings expectations, is raising its forecasts, painting an improved picture of what the second half of the year might look like. While it continues to expect the S&P 500 (SPX) will end 2017 below current levels, it sees greater contributions from both the financial and technology sectors, the latter of which has led the market higher thus far this year, despite persistent concerns about valuations.

David Kostin, the firm’s chief U.S. strategist, raised his year-end target for the S&P to 2,400 from 2,300. The higher target is about 1.6% below current levels.

“The prospect of accelerating inflation, higher policy rates, and rising 10-year bond yields will weigh on S&P 500 valuation,” the team of analysts wrote in a note to clients. “We expect earnings per share growth of 9% this year will be offset by a 4% contraction in the forward price-to-earnings multiple to 17.3 from 18.1.” Goldman forecast GDP growth of 2.1% in 2017, along with average yields of 2.6% for the U.S. 10-year Treasury note (BX:TMUBMUSD10Y) which is currently at 2.23%.

Related: Is Donald Trump boosting the economy? Goldman finds mixed signals

The relatively improved outlook comes amid growing profit expectations, and in addition to its higher target for the benchmark index, Goldman also raised its forecast for S&P earnings, to $129 a share from $123 in 2017, and to $139 from $129 a share for 2018. “The increase stems from strong first-quarter results and higher expected growth in Financials and Info Tech,” it wrote, reiterating its overweight positions on those sectors, which expects to grow earnings by 13% (financials) and 9% (tech).

The mean estimate of analysts polled by FactSet suggests 2017 earnings of $131.73 a share. This is down from the $135.25 a share estimate that was forecast at the end of April, though it is up from the December consensus view of $129.42 a share.

Goldman had previously been cautious on the market’s earnings picture. In February, it wrote that equities were “approaching the point of maximum optimism” and that “financial market reconciliation lies ahead,” referring to the divergence between profit forecasts and share-price gains. This was followed by another warning in May, when it wrote that “history strongly suggests that at some point this year investors will have to digest negative revisions to fourth-quarter earnings per share estimates.”

Earlier this month, Goldman wrote that markets were in a “Goldilocks scenario” that was unlikely to persist over the long term, and the expectation that markets will end the year below current levels suggests this still the cast.

“We recommend investors focus on companies with strong secular growth and margin expansion prospects,” Kostin’s team wrote, explicitly naming Facebook Inc. (FB) Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) Apple Inc. (AAPL) Microsoft Corp. (MSFT) and Google-parent Alphabet Inc. (GOOGL) as stocks that fit this criteria.

Read: A major value fund mirrors a major growth one more than you may expect

“Goldman Sachs analysts forecast these firms will grow revenues three times faster the market and have roughly two times the margins,” the note read.

item.title: Do Apple and Facebook have what it takes to succeed in TV?
item.dc:creator: Trey Williams
item.description: If Facebook Inc. and Apple Inc. want to succeed in TV they’re going to need money and audience. Good thing for them, they have both.
item.content:encoded:
By Trey Williams

Facebook boasts nearly 2 billion monthly users, while Apple has wooed entertainment execs to its table

If Facebook Inc. and Apple Inc. want to succeed in TV they’re going to need money and audience.

Good thing for them, they have both.

Competition in the TV landscape is already intense, and now Facebook (FB) is reportedly wining and dining Hollywood studios and talent agencies with the aim of producing original television programming.

The Wall Street Journal reported that the social media giant has held meetings with talent agencies, in which Facebook has said it’s willing to spend as much as $3 million per episode. That’s less than Netflix Inc. (NFLX) but more than Time Warner Inc.’s (TWX) HBO spends per episode on average.

Don’t miss: Netflix adds ‘Girlboss to the dump pile as its content production goals mature

Also, Apple (AAPL) has shown it’s serious about its desire to be a major content player. The company recently lured Sony Pictures Television executives Zack Van Amburg and Jamie Erlicht away from the studio where they oversaw such series as “Breaking Bad,” “Better Call Saul” and “The Crown.”

While Apple doesn’t exactly have $250 billion in cash to wave around, it certainly has the money to attract the talent it would take to deliver quality content.

The willingness and ability to spend exorbitantly to secure the best content is the only thing standing between Facebook, Apple and success, said BTIG analyst Rich Greenfield.

“There’s a ton of wallet out there and a ton of watch time,” Greenfield said. “I think this is just the beginning. The question is are these companies going to spend the kind of money necessary to have quality content.”

Apple has the money and it makes sense with the company’s distribution of other entertainment. Wedbush analyst Michael Pachter said there’s a clear path to Apple enticing consumers to pay for their original content.

See: Apple has taken its first step in original content

“That’s a natural extension of what Apple does,” Pachter said. “But I’m not sure what the end game for Facebook is.”

Facebook’s attraction is its audience and the data it has on them. Facebook boasts nearly 2 billion monthly users and all the company wants is for as many of those users as possible to engage with content on the platform. Facebook has already been able to parade its audience and ink deals with Major League Soccer and Major League Baseball to air games.

Also read: Google’s big European fine is likely bad news for Facebook, Amazon and others

Facebook’s video aspirations probably won’t look like the most others in the landscape. Pachter said the social platform probably won’t turn toward a subscription service. He points out that if Facebook prominently featured original series on users’ timelines and only 1% of them actually watched the shows, that’s two million viewers.

That’s a fraction of the number of eyeballs garnered by a lot of TV’s most-watched programing, but Pachter said it’s likely more than the number watching a lot of the series on Netflix and at $3 million an episode that has potential for a solid return on investment.

Shares of Facebook have gained nearly 33% in the year to date, while Apple shares have gained close to 26%. By comparison, the S&P 500 index (SPX) is up 9% in the year and the Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) is up more than 8%.

item.title: Judge denies Qualcomm motion to dismiss FTC’s competition lawsuit
item.dc:creator: Ted Greenwald
item.description: A U.S. federal judge ruled against Qualcomm Inc.’s motion to dismiss a Federal Trade Commission case arguing that the large supplier of smartphone chips used its position in the market to compete unfairly.
item.content:encoded:
THE WALL STREET JOURNAL
By Ted Greenwald

Chip supplier is engaged in a broad legal battle over its business practices

A U.S. federal judge ruled against Qualcomm Inc.’s motion to dismiss a Federal Trade Commission case arguing that the large supplier of smartphone chips used its position in the market to compete unfairly.

The Monday ruling by U.S. District Judge Lucy Koh is a setback—though not an unexpected one—in Qualcomm’s (QCOM) broad legal battle over its business practices. That fight includes a separate lawsuit filed by Apple Inc. (AAPL) against Qualcomm which makes legal arguments similar to the U.S. government’s.

Judge Koh’s decision that the government’s case could move forward rejected Qualcomm’s claim, filed in April in a Northern California federal district court, that the FTC’s complaint failed to support even basic elements of an antitrust violation.

The FTC says Qualcomm, whose technology is used in almost all smartphones, acts unfairly by refusing to sell its chips to handset makers who don’t buy a license to use its patents—which are deemed essential to cellular communications—and by refusing to sell licenses to competing chip makers. The government says Qualcomm further impaired competition by using its dominant position to compel Apple to use its chips exclusively.

item.title: Imagination puts itself up for sale as it battles Apple over chip designs
item.dc:creator: Sara Sjolin
item.description: Imagination Technologies Group shares surge 17% after the British chip designer says it is talking with potential bidders, after its shares lost half their value on the Apple news.
item.content:encoded:
MARKET EXTRA
By Sara Sjolin

Shares surge 16% as the chip designer says it is talking to potential bidders

Imagination Technologies Group PLC has put itself up for sale and is talking with potential bidders, after its shares lost more than half their value as Apple Inc. dropped the chip supplier.

The British tech company (UK:IMG) (IGNMF) — which designs the iPhone and iPad’s graphics chip — said Thursday that in recent weeks it has “received interest from a number of parties for a potential acquisition” of the whole group and “therefore decided to initiate a formal sale process.” It also said it is in early discussions with interested suitors.

Shares of Imagination soared 17% to £1.44 after the news on Thursday.

The company’s stock plunged 62% to £1.030 on April 3, after Imagination revealed that Apple (AAPL) planned to stop using its technology in new products within two years’ time. That means Imagination would not be eligible for royalty payments under the current license and royalty agreement with the California-based iPhone maker.

“Apple accounts for about half [Imagination’s] revenues, and the drop in the share price on the day of the announcement was one of the biggest on record for a mid or large-cap company, wrecking its market cap and forcing it to do all it could to shore up cash,” said Neil Wilson, senior market analyst at ETX Capital.

Wilson pointed out that Imagination had to tried to selloff two of its three main businesses — MIPS and Ensigma — to strengthen the balance sheet, but without success.

“These were both strong potential growth areas that could have delivered lasting revenue accretion to offset the loss of Apple,” he said.

“That was a pretty dire scenario, akin to selling off the family silver to keep the estate going a little longer. Now the shutters are up and a buyer sought. A pretty ignominious end to what was a great British tech success story,” he added.

Imagination’s shares closed at £1.235 on Wednesday, meaning they were still down 54% since the announcement about the contract loss in April.

Apple has been working on an independent in-house graphics chip architecture with the potential to reduce the need for Imagination technology in future iPhones, the British company has said. But it has questioned the iPhone maker’s ability to create an independent chip design without infringing on Imagination’s intellectual property rights, raising the prospect of a legal battle.

“Imagination believes that it would be extremely challenging to design a brand new [graphics processor unit] architecture from basics without infringing its intellectual property rights,” the company said in a statement at the time.

The chip designer said on Thursday “it remains in dispute with Apple” after being unable to reach an agreement.

Apple shares were down 0.4% early in Thursday’s trade.
